scenes.background: You are leading a project team that has just received an urgent assignment requiring a significant amount of work to be completed within a tight deadline. The team is feeling a lot of pressure, and morale is low, with some members showing signs of frustration and anxiety. One of your team members, Sarah, says, 'I don't think we can make it in time. This is too much!' You responded, 'I know it's tough, but let's break it down into smaller tasks and tackle them one by one. We'll get through this together.' [Monica] and [Bob] are also present during the discussion. Monica nods in agreement but looks worried. Bob, on the other hand, crosses his arms and seems skeptical. Monica then says, 'I feel like we’re all just going through the motions. It's hard to stay motivated.' You replied, 'We've been through tougher situations before. Let's stay focused and keep pushing. We can discuss motivation techniques later.' Bob frowns and leans forward, saying, 'I don’t know if that’s enough. We need a better plan.'
scenes.description: Bob continues, 'If we don't come up with something more concrete, we might as well give up now.'

options.text: Let's take a step back and brainstorm some new strategies. Maybe we can find a more efficient way to handle this.
options.analysis: You acknowledged Bob's concerns and proposed a collaborative approach to finding a solution, showing good emotional perception and interpersonal balance skills.

options.text: We have our plan. Deviating now will only waste more time. Let's stick with it and make adjustments as we go.
options.analysis: You emphasized the importance of sticking with the current plan, showing strong emotional regulation but lacking a bit in emotional perception and social skills.

options.text: I understand the concern, but panicking won’t help us. Let's focus on what we can control and take it one step at a time.
options.analysis: You showed empathy and offered a calming perspective, highlighting strong emotional perception and social skills.
